validation_metadata.verified_by: Claude Code AI Assistant - Manual Extraction
validation_metadata.verification_method: Complete manual review of K.S.A. 45-215 through 45-223

rights_of_access.description: It is the public policy of Kansas that public records shall be open for inspection by any person. This act shall be liberally construed and applied to promote such policy.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to interpretation of entire act; mandates broad construction favoring access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Strong directive to courts and agencies - doubt resolved in favor of disclosure; one of strongest liberal construction provisions nationally
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite policy: 'K.S.A. 45-216(a) requires liberal construction of KORA to promote openness. Any ambiguity must be resolved in favor of disclosure.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records are presumed to be open for inspection unless specifically exempted by statute. Any person may inspect public records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Presumption applies unless specific exemption cited; burden on agency to prove exemption
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Openness is default position; exemptions must be specifically established and proven
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert presumption: 'K.S.A. 45-218(a) presumes these records are open for inspection. Please provide access unless you can cite and prove a specific exemption applies.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must provide written response within 3 business days stating whether access will be granted. If records cannot be produced immediately, agency must notify requester of record custodian.
rights_of_access.conditions: 3 business days from receipt; must be written response; must grant, deny, or redirect
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Quick response requirement ensures requesters aren't left in limbo; written requirement creates documentation
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand response: 'K.S.A. 45-218(d) requires written response within 3 business days stating whether access will be granted. Please respond within this statutory deadline.'

rights_of_access.description: Written explanation required for any denial of access. Agencies must cite specific statutory basis for withholding.
rights_of_access.conditions: Denial must be in writing; must cite specific exemption statute; vague denials improper
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Prevents agencies from simply refusing without justification; requester receives specific legal basis for challenge
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand specificity: 'K.S.A. 45-218(f) requires written explanation citing the specific statutory exemption for any denial. Please provide detailed written justification.'

rights_of_access.description: Records must be provided during regular office hours. Agencies must make records available for inspection during normal business operations.
rights_of_access.conditions: During regular office hours; agencies set reasonable hours for access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Ensures consistent availability; requesters can plan visits during known business hours
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request inspection: 'Under K.S.A. 45-218(b), please provide access to [records] during your regular office hours. What are your hours for public records inspection?'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot place unreasonable burden on production of records. Requests must be accommodated unless truly burdensome.
rights_of_access.conditions: Burden must be unreasonable to justify limitation; agencies must demonstrate unreasonableness
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Protects against agencies claiming any effort is too burdensome; burden must be genuinely unreasonable
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge burden claim: 'K.S.A. 45-218(e) prohibits unreasonable burdens. Please explain specifically why my request imposes an unreasonable burden and cannot be accommodated.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must separate exempt from non-exempt information. Statistical information not describing identifiable persons may be disclosed even if other portions are exempt.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must redact only exempt portions; public portions disclosed; applies when records contain mixed content
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot withhold entire document; must identify and separate exempt portions; statistical/aggregate data often releasable
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand segregation: 'K.S.A. 45-221(a) requires you to separate and disclose non-exempt portions. Please provide redacted records showing what specific information is withheld.'

rights_of_access.description: Public agency bears the burden of proving that a record is exempt from disclosure. Requester does not have burden to prove entitlement.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies in all judicial proceedings; agency must establish exemption applies; requester need not justify access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Burden-shifting protects requesters - you don't prove you deserve records; agency must prove exemption
rights_of_access.request_tips: In court: 'Under K.S.A. 45-222(c), your agency bears the burden of proving this exemption applies. I need not prove my entitlement to these public records.'

rights_of_access.description: Court determines public records matters de novo - fresh review without deference to agency decision. Court conducts independent evaluation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies in all judicial proceedings under KORA; court reviews matter anew; no deference to agency
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Independent judicial review; agency gets no deference or presumption of correctness; court decides afresh
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note review standard: 'K.S.A. 45-222(c) provides for de novo court review - the judge will independently evaluate whether records should be disclosed, not simply defer to your agency's decision.'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Attorney Fees for Bad Faith Denials
rights_of_access.description: If court finds agency's denial was not in good faith, plaintiff can recover reasonable attorney fees, court costs, and other litigation expenses.
rights_of_access.conditions: Denial must be in bad faith; fees must be reasonable; court discretion based on good faith finding
rights_of_access.applies_to: Prevailing plaintiffs where agency acted in bad faith
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee-shifting punishes bad faith denials; encourages agencies to act reasonably; makes enforcement financially viable
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of fees: 'K.S.A. 45-222(d) provides for attorney fees if your denial is found to be in bad faith. Please ensure your exemption claims are made in good faith.'

rights_of_access.description: Courts can require defendant public agencies to complete open records training as remedy for violations. Ensures future compliance.
rights_of_access.conditions: Court may order as remedy; applies to agencies found in violation; ensures education to prevent future violations
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Unique remedial provision - court can order training to improve agency practices; prevents repeat violations
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request in litigation: 'Under K.S.A. 45-222(c), I request the court order your agency to complete open records training if violations are found.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must make reasonable efforts to contact requesters when staff time will exceed 5 hours or estimated cost will exceed $200. Allows requester to narrow or modify request.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required when time >5 hours or cost >$200; agency must contact before proceeding; gives requester opportunity to modify
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Prevents surprise large bills; allows requesters to prioritize or narrow scope before costs accrue
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert right: 'If costs will exceed $200 or require over 5 hours under K.S.A. 45-218, you must contact me before proceeding so I can narrow the request if needed.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may file complaints with Kansas Attorney General's Office regarding KORA violations. AG provides guidance and reviews complaints.
rights_of_access.conditions: Informal complaint process; AG provides guidance not binding determinations; accessible at (785) 296-2215
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Administrative option before litigation; AG office provides expertise; no fee for complaint
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference AG: 'I may file a complaint with the Kansas Attorney General's Office at (785) 296-2215 regarding your handling of this request.'

rights_of_access.description: Any person denied access may bring civil action in district court for injunction, mandamus, or declaratory judgment to compel disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: File in district court; multiple remedy types available (injunction, mandamus, declaratory judgment); cases assigned at earliest practicable date
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Direct judicial access; no administrative exhaustion required; court prioritizes these cases for quick resolution
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note enforcement: 'K.S.A. 45-222(a) authorizes me to seek injunction, mandamus, or declaratory judgment in district court if this denial continues. Cases are expedited.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records include any recorded information, regardless of form or characteristics. Electronic, paper, photographic, and all other media are covered.
rights_of_access.conditions: Medium-neutral definition; applies to all formats including electronic databases, recordings, photographs, etc.
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records regardless of storage format
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Ensures electronic records have same accessibility as paper; agencies cannot deny based on electronic format
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic records: 'K.S.A. 45-217 defines public records as information regardless of form. Please provide access to [database/electronic files] which are public records under this definition.'

rights_of_access.description: Records over 70 years old are generally open for inspection. Historical records have enhanced accessibility.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to records more than 70 years old; presumption of access; some exceptions may still apply
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Recognizes historical value and reduced privacy concerns for older records; supports historical research
rights_of_access.request_tips: For historical records: 'These records are over 70 years old and K.S.A. 45-221 presumes they are open for inspection.'
